What is the `revokeidentity` command in Verus, and how can I use it to revoke an identity?

The `revokeidentity` command in Verus is used to revoke an identity, which is a crucial feature in maintaining control over one's digital identity. To use this command, you need to provide the unique name or ID of the identity you want to revoke, along with some optional parameters.

Here's the basic syntax of the command:
```
revokeidentity "nameorID" (returntx) (tokenrevoke) (feeoffer) (sourceoffunds)
```
Let's break down the arguments:

* `nameorID`: This is the unique name or ID of the identity you want to revoke. It's a required string argument.
* `returntx`: This is an optional boolean argument that defaults to `false`. If set to `true`, the transaction will be signed by your wallet and returned instead of being sent.
* `tokenrevoke`: This is an optional boolean argument that defaults to `false`. If set to `true`, the tokenized ID control token, if it exists, will be used to revoke the identity.
* `feeoffer`: This is an optional value argument that allows you to specify a non-standard fee amount to pay for the transaction.
* `sourceoffunds`: This is an optional string argument that allows you to specify a transparent or private address to source all funds for fees, which helps preserve the privacy of the identity.

When you run the `revokeidentity` command, it will return a JSON object with the following properties:

* `txid`: The transaction ID of the revocation transaction.
* `namereservation`: An object containing information about the name reservation, including the unique name, salt, referral, parent, and name ID.

Here are some examples of how to use the `revokeidentity` command:
```
> verus revokeidentity "nameorID"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "revokeidentity", "params": ["nameorID"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```
By using the `revokeidentity` command, you can effectively revoke an identity and maintain control over your digital presence.

### `revokeidentity "nameorID" (returntx) (tokenrevoke) (feeoffer) (sourceoffunds)`
#### Arguments:
```
"nameorID"            (string, required) the unique name to commit to. creating a name commitment is not a registration, and if one is
                           created for a name that exists, it may succeed, but will never be able to be used.
"returntx"            (bool,  optional) defaults to false and transaction is sent, if true, transaction is signed by this wallet and returned
"tokenrevoke"           (bool,  optional) defaults to false, if true, the tokenized ID control token, if one exists, will be used to revoke
"feeoffer"            (value, optional) non-standard fee amount to pay for the transaction
"sourceoffunds"          (string, optional) transparent or private address to source all funds for fees to preserve privacy of the identity```
#### Result:
```json
{
  "txid" : "hexid"
  "namereservation" :
  {
    "name"  : "namestr",   (string) the unique name in this commitment
    "salt"  : "hexstr",   (hex)  salt used to hide the commitment
    "referral": "identityaddress", (base58) address of the referring identity if there is one
    "parent" : "namestr",   (string) name of the parent if not Verus or Verus test
    "nameid" : "address",   (base58) identity address for this identity if it is created
  }
}
```
### Examples:
```bash
> verus revokeidentity "nameorID"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "revokeidentity", "params": ["nameorID"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```
